'''''Lactarius quietus''''' (commonly known as the '''oak milkcap''', '''oakbug milkcap''' or '''southern milkcap''') is a mushroom of the genus ''[[Lactarius]]''. It is easily identified by its oily scent and the [[concentric]] bands on its cap. It is brown, and is probably named after its matt, "quiet" surface and colouration. It is found exclusively under oak trees in Europe, where it grows solitarily or in scattered groups in autumn months. In North America, the [[variety (botany)|variety]] ''L. quietus'' var. ''incanus'' is fairly common in the same habitat. The mushroom's edibility is disputed.

==Taxonomy and naming==
''L. quietus'' was first described and named by Swedish mycologist [[Elias Magnus Fries]],<ref name="Cooke">{{cite book |title= British Edible Fungi|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=lOrahbcWdKAC&pg=PA230&dq=%22Lactarius+quietus%22&lr=lang_en&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES&client=firefox-a|last= Cooke|first= M.C.|year= 2007|publisher= Read Books|isbn= 978-1-4067-5608-1|page= 230}}</ref> who named it ''Agaricus quietus'' in the first volume of his ''[[Systema Mycologicum]]'', published in 1821.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.mycobank.org/MycoTaxo.aspx?Link=T&Rec=241249|title= ''Agaricus quietus'' Fr. 1821 |publisher= [[MycoBank]]|accessdate=1 January 2011}}</ref> In his later ''Epicrisis Systematis Mycologici'', published in 1838, Fries transferred the species to ''Lactarius''.<ref name="MB">{{cite web |url= http://www.mycobank.org/MycoTaxo.aspx?Link=T&Rec=157234|title= ''Lactarius quietus'' (Fr.) Fr. 1838|publisher= [[MycoBank]]|accessdate=1 January 2011}}</ref> Subsequent attempts to reclassify the species were unsuccessful; in 1871, [[Paul Kummer]] described the species as a member of ''Galorrheus'', and in 1891 [[Otto Kuntze]] classified it as ''Lactifluus'', but today Fries's placement of the species in ''Lactarius'' is accepted.<ref name="MB"/> The [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]] [[wikt:quietus|''quietus'']] means "quiet" or "calm", and is possibly used to refer to the unintrusive colours of the cap.<ref name="Roody"/>

The [[variety (botany)|variety]] ''Lactarius quietus'' var. ''unicolor'' was described by Fries in the second volume of his ''Monographia Hymenomycetum Sueciae'', published in 1863.<ref>"[http://www.mycobank.org/MycoTaxo.aspx?Link=T&Rec=494045 ''Lactarius quietus var. unicolor'' Fr. 1863]". [[MycoBank]]. Accessed 1 January 2011.</ref> The variety ''Lactarius quietus'' var. ''incanus'' was described by [[Lexemuel Ray Hesler]] and [[Alexander H. Smith]] in their 1979 ''North American species of Lactarius''.<ref>"[http://www.indexfungorum.org/names/NamesRecord.asp?RecordID=117727 ''Lactarius quietus'' var. ''incanus'']". [[Index Fungorum]]. Accessed 1 January 2011.</ref> The name ''incanus'' translates as :hoary", referring to the whited bloom which can sometimes be seen on the mushrooms.<ref name="Roody"/>

''Lactarius quietus'' is known by the [[common name]]s oak milkcap,<ref name="Phillips"/><ref name="Jordan"/> oakbug milkcap<ref name="RogersMushrooms">{{cite web |url= http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~6331.asp|title= Lactarius quietus|accessdate=2009-02-10 |last= Phillips|first= Roger|publisher= RogersMushrooms}}</ref><ref name="Sterry"/> and the southern milkcap.<ref name="Hall">{{cite book |title= Edible and Poisonous Mushrooms of the World|last= Hall|first= Ian Robert|year= 2003|publisher= [[Timber Press]]|isbn= 978-0-88192-586-9|page= 316|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=yqHA_M7BVRcC&pg=PA316&dq=%22Lactarius+quietus%22&lr=lang_en&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES&client=firefox-a#PPA316,M1}}</ref> ''Lactarius quietus'' var. ''incanus'' is commonly known as the burnt sugar lactarius.<ref name="Roody"/>

==Description==
[[File:Lactarius spec. - Lindsey 9b.jpg|thumb|left|''L. quietus'' gills and milk]]
''L. quietus'' typically has a convex [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] of {{convert|5|to|8|cm|in}} across, which later flattens or develops a small depression in the centre. In colour, the cap is a dull reddish brown with a tint of [[cinnamon]], sometimes with darker [[concentric]] bands or spots.<ref name="Phillips">{{cite book |title= Mushrooms and Other Fungi of Great Britain and Europe|last= Phillips|first= Roger|year= 1981|publisher= [[Pan Books]]|location= London|isbn= 0-330-26441-9|page= 83}}</ref> This zoning is one of the most distinctive features of the species.<ref name="Pegler">{{cite book |title= Mushrooms and Toadstools|last= Pegler|first= David N.|year= 1983|publisher= Mitchell Beazley Publishing|location= London|isbn= 0-85533-500-9|page= 115}}</ref> The cap is dry and matt, and not sticky when moist. It features a thick layer of firm, whitish-buff flesh.<ref name="Phillips"/> The [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] measures from {{convert|4|to|9|cm|in}} in height, and is typically {{convert|10|to|15|mm|in}} thick. It is cylindrical in shape, but is sometimes furrowed lengthways,<ref name="Phillips"/> and it lacks a [[volva (mycology)|ring]].<ref name="Jordan"/> It is concolorous with the cap, or a little darker, and is sometimes hollow.<ref name="Phillips"/> The brownish-white [[Lamella (mycology)|gills]] are slightly decurrent, and change colour with age to a pale reddish brown with mauve hints. The [[latex|milk]] is white or cream in colour.<ref name="Phillips"/> The mushroom has a distinctive, strong [[oil]]y smell,<ref name="Pegler"/> which has also been likened to [[Bed bug (insect)|bedbug]]s and wet laundry.<ref name="Sterry"/> The spores are oval, with plentiful warts joined by numerous ridges, forming a well-developed network. The spores typically measure 7.5 to 9 by 6.5 to 7.5 [[µm]], and leave a cream print.<ref name="Phillips"/>

===var. ''incanus''===
''L. quietus'' var. ''incanus'' is typically slightly larger than the nominate variety, and younger specimens feature a whitish bloom, after which the variant is named. It has a sweet smell reminiscent of [[maple syrup]], and can be commonly found under oak trees. It can be confused with ''[[Lactarius aquifluus|L. aquifluus]]'' and ''[[Lactarius mutabilis|L. mutabilis]]'', but both of these species are found in coniferous woodland.<ref name="Roody">{{cite book |title= Mushrooms of West Virginia and the Central Appalachians|last= Roody|first= William C.|year= 2003|publisher= [[University Press of Kentucky]]|isbn= 978-0-8131-9039-6|page= 101|accessdate= 2008-08-18|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=5HGMPEiy4ykC&pg=PA82&dq=%22Lactarius+quietus%22&lr=lang_en&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES&client=firefox-a#PPA101,M1}}</ref>

==Edibility==
''Lactarius quietus'' has been variously described as edible<ref name="Cooke"/><ref name="Phillips"/> and inedible.<ref name="Jordan"/><ref name="Pegler"/> The milk has a mild or slightly bitter taste.<ref name="Phillips"/> ''L. quietus'' var. ''incanus'' also has conflicting reports concerning its edibility, and so is not recommended.<ref name="Roody"/>

==Habitat, ecology and areas of spreading==
''L. quietus'' is found growing exclusively at the base of [[oak]] trees,<ref name="Pegler"/> solitarily or in scattered groups, in soil.<ref name="Jordan">{{cite book |title= The Encyclopedia of Fungi of Britain and Europe|last= Jordan|first= Michael|year= 2004|publisher= [[Frances Lincoln]]|isbn= 978-0-7112-2379-0|page= 306|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=bFMfytLn3bEC&pg=PA306&dq=%22Lactarius+quietus%22&lr=lang_en&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES&client=firefox-a}}</ref> It can be found very commonly throughout autumn months.<ref name="Phillips"/> It is [[Mycorrhizal#Ectomycorrhiza|ectomycorrhizal]], feeding symbiotically exclusively with oak,<ref>{{cite journal |author= Luschka, Norbert|year= 1997|title= Macrofungi in Central German Floodplain Forests|journal= Global Ecology and Biogeography Letters|publisher= [[Blackwell Publishing]]|volume= 6|issue= 3/4|pages= 231–5|issn= 0960-7447}}</ref> though studies have suggested it is also able to feed [[saprotrophically]], growing from organic soil matter.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Courtya, Pierre-Emmanuel |author2=Brédab, Nathalie |author3=Garbayea, Jean |year= 2006|title= Relation between oak tree phenology and the secretion of organic matter degrading enzymes by ''Lactarius quietus'' ectomycorrhizas before and during bud break|journal= Soil Biology and Biochemistry|volume= 39|issue= 7|pages= 1655–63|doi= 10.1016/j.soilbio.2007.01.017}}</ref> ''L. quietus'' can be found only in Europe; in the [[United Kingdom]], it is one of the one hundred most commonly encountered mushroom species.<ref name="Sterry">{{cite book |title= Complete Guide to British Mushrooms & Toadstools|author1=Sterry, Paul |author2=Hughes, Barry |year= 2009|publisher= [[HarperCollins]]|isbn= 978-0-00-723224-6|page= 58}}</ref> ''L. quietus'' var. ''incanus'' is found commonly in eastern North America.<ref name="Kuo">{{cite web |url= http://www.mushroomexpert.com/lactarius_quietus_incanus.html|title= Lactarius quietus var. incanus|accessdate=2009-02-10 |last= Kuo|first= Michael|date=March 2005|publisher= MushroomExpert.com}}</ref>
